Speaker: Ms VAMVAKINOU
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I look forward to the assistance of the honourable member for Fisher to getting a Medicare office in the area of Sunbury in my electorate, where we are in desperate need of a Medicare office as well. This evening I would like to bring to the attention of the House a public meeting that I attended last Sunday in my electorate of Calwell regarding the government's decision to build a new detention facility. The meeting was attended by a great number of local residents who are very concerned and opposed to this facility being built in Broadmeadows. My community's campaign to oppose this detention centre will focus on the theme of ‘Links not locks' and is best illustrated by the comments made by Mr John Rutherford, Secretary of the Broadmeadows Progress Association. He made a very valid point at Sunday's meeting: History graphically illustrates that detention tres, whether they are called concentration camps, strategic hamlets, Indian reservations or nal reserves, do not solve problems, but create new ones. I want to join with my community and bring to the government's attention that in my electorate we have many problems and issues without having to add more unnecessarily. We believe that the $120 million that is earmarked to be spent on building this facility would be better spent on addressing the many social, economic and infrastructure problems that affect the daily lives of people in Calwell. We are therefore appalled by the lack of consultation from this government. The decision to nominate Maygar Barracks as a preferred site was taken without consultation with the local community. Whilst the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has now offered to work with council to consult the community, this process focuses on the nature of the facility rather than whether this is an appropriate site. In light of this, Hume City Council commissioned a research report to assess community opinion of the detention centre proposal. It is a shame DIMIA did not undertake a similar activity, as the results were extremely enlightening. Some 69 per cent of those surveyed oppose the proposal to build the Broadmeadows facility and 80 per cent are opposed to the federal government spending $120 million to build a new detention centre altogether. My community believes that there are far better uses for the land at Maygar Barracks, uses that would generate much needed employment and yield greater social benefits. This site on Camp Road is close to Melbourne airport, the Hume Highway, the Calder Highway and the P&O operated inland rail/road freight interchange facility. An incendependent analysis of the site has highlighted the economic benefits of the site, which can aborigi- generate substantially more employment than that generated by a detention centre facility. The economic research also showed that the site is on a prime business and industrial site, which is linked by road, rail and air networks. It showed that a detention centre was not a good use of the land and it would generate only around 150 jobs-far fewer than the 3,900 direct and indirect jobs that could be generated if the land were used for more strategic purposes and far, far fewer than the 8,000 direct and indirect jobs generated nationally if the land were used to develop a high-tech industry base. My community is also concerned about the nature of detention policy and its human ramifications. At a time when the government is conceding that not all asylum seekers need to be detained, and with women and children being relocated into the community, it is unnecessary and inappropriate to allocate $120 million of taxpayers' money to an additional 200-bed detention facility. This is a huge amount of money that could be far better spent for the benefit of the community. In my electorate-and in many, many others-there are critical issues that should be addressed with a higher priority than another detention centre. The government should be spending this money on increasing bulkbilling, providing more aged care beds, addressing the apprenticeships shortfall, ing more child-care places or reinstating matter of urgency-certainly to the people in my electorate-the Commonwealth dental health scheme. The Broadmeadows community vigorously opposes this proposed detention centre. It is inconsistent with the hopes and aspirations of our culturally diverse community, which is working hard to transform itself and its image. Broadmeadows is on the road to significant social redevelopment. We want government spending to aid that development, not stymie it. To that end, I have cosigned a joint letter with the Hume City Council to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, Senator Amanda Vanstone, requesting a meeting with me and a delegation from Hume City Council to discuss this issue and to present the minister with a banner, signed by local residents, opposing this proposed detention facility. I do hope that the minister, Senator Vanstone, will accommodate this meeting and give my community the opportunity to raise with her concerns that are very legitimate. (Time expired) Religious Extremists

Speaker: Ms PANOPOULOS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: In recent times we have witnessed disturbing statements from some Muslim extremists who live in this country, and I want to talk briefly about them in this House tonight. Brunswick Sheikh Mohammed Omran claimed recently that Osama bin Laden was ‘a great man'. He disputed the involvement of bin Laden in ‘any evil action' in relation to the September 11 attacks or, for that matter, that of ‘any Muslim at all'. With statements such as these from religious figures in our community, Australians rightly feel very concerned and worried that our age of innocence has well and truly passed. But more recently we have had the fightfund- ing words of Abu Bakr. His passport was as a recently revoked by ASIO on the basis that he would ‘engage in conduct that might prejudice the security of Australia or a foreign country'. In late June ASIO officers raided his suburban Melbourne home and took some papers-after which, surprisingly, he cried foul. Is it any wonder that ASIO acted in this way? For a bloke who claims that ‘Jihad is part of my religion,' and ‘My religion doesn't tolerate other religions,' a mere security raid on his home seems relatively light-handed. Even more disturbing are Bakr's claims that ‘There are two laws: there is an Australian law and there is an Islamic law' and ‘The only law which needs to spread has to be Islam.' If that is not disturbing enough, aside from support for suicide bombers, I do not know what is. With these bombastic statements, one might legitimately question whether we want the people who are making such inflammatory and extremist comments in our country at all. Only yesterday we had a spokesman for Hizb ut-Tahrir, Wassim Doureihi, after defending jihad and the suicide bombers, claiming that the prevention of loss of innocent life could be dealt with by addressing original grievances. In other words, it is the West's fault again: we are at the root of all evil and we are causing all the excuses and all the reasons for suicide bombers to exist. This is unacceptable, and we cannot sit by and allow such ridiculous comments of hatred to go past uncommented on. The Blair government needs to be commended, as it has recently confronted some of these issues. Soon Australian legislators, as the Prime Minister has foreshadowed, should do the same. Citizenship should come with responsibility: an unqualified and undivided loyalty. Citizenship should not be as trivial as a trinket in a cornflakes packet; it should mean something. It should not be a permanent convenience to receive taxpayer funded services and a passport well respected and accepted around the world. In Australia we value the separation of church and state. Religious figures can and often do speak out on all sorts of public policy issues. In a democracy, everyone can have a say. Freedom of speech and thought are ancient democratic principles, won in this country not through civil war or bloodshed but largely through peaceful governments and through our society. Whilst we enjoy freedom of expression and diversity, this should not be confused with a conflict of basic values. So when radicals and zealots publicly espouse values and ideals that are anathema to our own, as we have seen with some extremist Muslim leaders recently, we should not be intimidated by some perverse sense of tolerance into remaining silent. We need to be vocal in telling these radical Muslim clerics and their followers that suicide bombing and terrorist attacks on innocent citizens are not acceptable processes for criticising government actions or formulating public policy. These extremists are breeding hatred-a dangerous hatred that aims to destroy the very pillars of this great nation. The reality is that Australia remains the most free and most tolerant egalitarian and decent society in the world. Let us face it: now is not the time to walk on the eggshells of political correctness. Let us accept the fact that Muslim extremists live in Australia. They do not accept our open and democratic society. They think we are infidels and that we deserve what is coming to us in the form of terrorism. We must vigorously defend our democratic civilisation and our rule of lawone law for all Australians-and our way of life without fear or favour. (Time expired) Government Accountability

Speaker: Ms GRIERSON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: For the first time since the Fraser era 24 years ago, a Prime Minister now has control of both houses of the Australian parliament. With Senator Robert Hill already talking about diminishing Senate estimates powers, holding John Howard and his government to account will be challenging. Media reports suggest that holding the Howard government to account will be the domain of individual parliamentarians willing to step across the coalition ‘party line'-implying that Barnaby Joyce or National Party renegades will shape the government agenda. While they may be able to influence, it is important not to confuse horse-trading with accountability. A $2 billion or $5 billion pay off to rural Australia might make National Party members and Barnaby Joyce feel better about selling out on Telstra

Speaker: Ms GRIERSON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Senator Joyce, I am sorry-but it will not ensure service delivery obligations are met by a fully privatised Telstra. At best it may save some of their skins at the next election when, for ordinary Australians living in cities, towns or the bush, the internet will still be too slow, the mobile will still drop out, the wait for phone repairs will still take over three months and rental and call charges will increase unchecked by government regulation. Accountability is a much more difficult process than trade-offs, rorts and vote buying. It involves rigorous scrutiny of all operations of government and their bureaucracies, whose complex processes can too often overwhelm ordinary Australians-ordinary Australians like Cornelia Rau, Vivian Solon or the 200 other people who may have been wrongfully detained by DIMIA. The government tried to hide these people under a bureaucratic curtain until exposed by public advocates, journalists and opposition members of parliament. After public outcry the Palmer inquiry was undertaken to investigate the actions of this government departmenta department its report found to be ‘overly self-protective and defensive, a culture largely unwilling to challenge organisational norms or to engage in self-criticism or analytralian sis'. All this was achieved with not a Barnaby Joyce in sight! In July, the ANAO released its damning report into the management of detention centre contracts, finding that DIMIA had no idea if the Australian taxpayer was receiving value for money for contracts worth around $120 million per year to American jailers Global Solutions Ltd. Worse, it found that the contracts gave DIMIA no way of knowing whether the basic needs of detainees are being met or their human rights are being respected. But Minister Vanstone is yet to be held accountable for her neglect. Importantly, it was the Labor opposition that drew to the public's attention that Mick Palmer had vacated his position as Inspector of Transport Security to conduct the Rau inquiry, with no-one acting in his place. Similarly, alarmed by the allegations of tematic drug movements through passenger baggage at our airports, antics with camel suits at Sydney airport and a string of other security breaches, the Labor members of the Joint Public Accounts and Audit Committee successfully moved that the aviation security inquiry be reopened. Unable to hide from public scrutiny, the government initiated its own inquiry under Sir John Wheeler-just in time, given the reminder from the tragic London bombings that there is no room for complacency when it comes to the safety and security of Australians in a world where rorism must always be considered a risk factor. As parliament returns there is an awakening amongst ordinary Australians that the greatly enhanced power of the government will now be turned against them in their workplaces. The Howard government suggests this new workplace relations front is part of the battle to save the Australian way of life. According to Howard's way, the Ausway of life will be at risk unless Senator working people lose as many minimum award standards as possible, such as meal breaks, holiday pay, penalty rates and the new maternity, paternity and personal family leave provisions; unless they do without a national wage case to set a liveable minimum wage and forgo their independent umpire. Moving people from secure permanent employment onto employer dictated AWAs will apparently make us more Australian! And the Prime Minister intends to spend much more than $20 million of our taxpayers' money to wage this new war over the ‘Australian way of life'. The Australian people do not live in a soap opera constructed by spin doctors and PR gurus. They live and work in families and in communities, all sharing the same goalsto be able to do an honest day's work for a sys- fair day's pay so they can make ends meet and be sure that their loved ones have the opportunities they so richly deserve. Now more than ever before, the checks and balances of parliamentary accountability will be brought to bear by the Labor opposition to make sure the government's new power does not overwhelm ordinary Australians and undermine the quality of life hard-fought for and won by generations of working people of this nation. Senator Barnaby Joyce can get on board for the working people of Queensland if he likes. ter- Lifestyle and Rural Green Overlay Protest

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I want to report on a protest meeting held in Rouse Hill, one of the outer suburbs of Sydney, last weekend where 1,500 people turned out on a sunny Sunday afternoon to protest against some of the crazy, oppressive decisions they are being confronted with by the New South Wales government. These proposals deal with property rights of individuals who have bought their land and who are expecting a reasonable market value return on sale. The New South Wales government has not changed the zone but has restricted the opportunities for the use of that land. that land being able to be used for future housing development, which is clearly stated on every title, the New South Wales government has restricted the use of that land to lifestyle and rural. It is called the lifestyle and rural green overlay. It means that if a farmer is using that land, they cannot increase their production or change their production. They have to get approval from the New South Wales government before they can vary it. If the land is not being used for primary production, then the use of the land is frozen. Natural trees-that is, eucalypts and other indigenous species growing on the land-cannot be removed without appeal to the New South Wales government. This has changed the outlook for many residents of a large section of Sydney. This provision does not just apply to north-western Sydney; this provision applies to land right around the fringe of the city. It applies in the federal electorates of Mitchell, Macquarie, Lindsay, Greenway and Macarthur. All these electorates and others are affected by this strange announcement that land will be frozen to its current use and no potential exists for development. The impact of this announcement is to have land values halved or reduced by 75 per cent, because instead of there being a speculative value for eventual development for housing, which may be many years away, that opportunity is being denied by these changes. As I said, some 1,500 people from north-western Sydney turned out to protest against this. The meeting was arranged by local community organisations and chaired by Councillor Ray Williams. Speakers at the meeting included John Aquilina, the Speaker of the New South Wales parliament, Colleen Attard, John Brogden and Bernie Moriarty. They and a number of other speakers presented the case against these proposals of the Instead of New South Wales government. People's investment has been absolutely destroyed as any opportunity of selling their land for real market value in their declining years has been removed. They now have a limitation unexpectedly placed on their land. This is the proposition that I would put to the New South Wales government: you have destroyed the opportunity and the potential for many people to retire with dignity, and the property rights of individuals have been destroyed with no prospect of compensation. The Commonwealth Constitution requires us to pay market value for land which is resumed or on which the zoning is changed, but that is not necessary under New South Wales provisions. Zonings can be changed and land can be resumed without fair compensation being paid in every instance. Fair compensation should be paid to land owners in this instance or the state government should buy the land or this green overlay should be removed. There has been a cursory investigation of why the green overlay is required, but I suspect that the real reason is the current imposition of a $65,000 charge per block of developed land imposed by the previous Carr government, carried on by the current government, which seeks to raise $65,000 tax for the New South Wales government from every property. I believe that at a later stage, after properties which have been devalued by this process have been sold to developers, the New South Wales government will change the overlay and allow the land to once more be used for housing. (Time expired)
